origin: Late Middle English (as a verb in the sense ‘check or verify accounts’, especially by referring to a duplicate register): from Anglo-Norman French contreroller ‘keep a copy of a roll of accounts’, from medieval Latin contrarotulare, from contrarotulus ‘copy of a roll’, from contra- ‘against’ + rotulus ‘a roll’. The noun is perhaps via French contrôle.

definitions.definition: The power to influence or direct people's behavior or the course of events.
definitions.example: the whole operation is under the control of a production manager

definitions.definition: A group or individual used as a standard of comparison for checking the results of a survey or experiment.
definitions.example: they saw no difference between the cancer patients and the controls

definitions.definition: A member of an intelligence organization who personally directs the activities of a spy.
definitions.example: he sat with his KGB control as the details of his new assignment were explained

definitions.definition: A high card that will prevent the opponents from establishing a particular suit.
Determine the behavior or supervise the running of.
definitions.example: he was appointed to control the company's marketing strategy

definitions.definition: Take into account (an extraneous factor that might affect results) when performing an experiment.
definitions.example: no attempt was made to control for variations
